StudyObjective: To investigate the neural correlates of cognitive control processes using fMRI tasks and behavioral assessments.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A classic inhibitory control task measuring both reaction time and error rates in response to no-go stimuli.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In this study, the Go/No-Go task included 4 blocks, each with 30 trials. Each trial lasted 2 seconds, with a 1-second inter-trial interval. Subjects were instructed to press a button upon seeing 'go' stimuli and to refrain from pressing for 'no-go' stimuli.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Subjects rested with eyes open for baseline functional connectivity measurements.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed a 5-minute resting-state scan in a single continuous run, instructed to keep their eyes open and minimize movement.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Each participant saw a list of 20 words (one word every 2 seconds), followed by a 30-second distractor task. Then, they had 1 minute to recall as many words as possible.

StudyObjective: Investigate the neural correlates of four distinct dimensions of Formal Thought Disorder (FTD) in psychosis.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A classic inhibitory control task measuring both reaction time and error rates in response to no-go stimuli.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In this study, the Go/No-Go task included 4 blocks, each with 30 trials. Each trial lasted 2 seconds, with a 1-second inter-trial interval. Subjects were instructed to press a button upon seeing 'go' stimuli and to refrain from pressing for 'no-go' stimuli.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Subjects rested with eyes open for baseline functional connectivity measurements.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed a 5-minute resting-state scan in a single continuous run, instructed to keep their eyes open and minimize movement.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Each participant saw a list of 20 words (one word every 2 seconds), followed by a 30-second distractor task. Then, they had 1 minute to recall as many words as possible.

StudyObjective: Investigate the neural correlates of trait self-boundarylessness using fMRI tasks and behavioral assessments.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants rested with eyes open for baseline functional connectivity measurements.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed a 5-minute resting-state scan in a single continuous run, instructed to keep their eyes open and minimize movement.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A classic inhibitory control task measuring both reaction time and error rates in response to no-go stimuli.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In this study, the Go/No-Go task included 4 blocks, each with 30 trials. Each trial lasted 2 seconds, with a 1-second inter-trial interval. Subjects were instructed to press a button upon seeing 'go' stimuli and to refrain from pressing for 'no-go' stimuli.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Each participant saw a list of 20 words (one word every 2 seconds), followed by a 30-second distractor task. Then, they had 1 minute to recall as many words as possible within one minute.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Each participant saw a list of 20 words (one word every 2 seconds), followed by a 30-second distractor task. Then, they had 1 minute to recall as many words as possible within one minute.

StudyObjective: Accurate localization and coactivation profiles of the frontal eye field and inferior frontal junction: an ALE and MACM fMRI meta-analysis

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A classic inhibitory control task measuring both reaction time and error rates in response to no-go stimuli.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In this study, the Go/No-Go task included 4 blocks, each with 30 trials. Each trial lasted 2 seconds, with a 1-second inter-trial interval. Subjects were instructed to press a button upon seeing 'go' stimuli and to refrain from pressing for 'no-go' stimuli.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants rested with eyes open for baseline functional connectivity measurements.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed a 5-minute resting-state scan in a single continuous run, instructed to keep their eyes open and minimize movement.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Each participant saw a list of 20 words (one word every 2 seconds), followed by a 30-second distractor task. Then, they had 1 minute to recall as many words as possible.

StudyObjective: Investigate the neural correlates of reality‐monitoring and self‐monitoring.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants were asked to judge whether information was previously self‐generated or derived from outside.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Reality‐monitoring tasks included encoding and retrieval phases, with self‐generated and nonself‐generated stimuli.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants performed tasks requiring them to judge whether their movements were their own or not.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Self‐monitoring tasks included encoding and retrieval phases, with congruent and incongruent feedback.

StudyObjective: Evaluate how neural sensitivity to popular and unpopular peers in adolescents' school-based social networks is associated with changes in risk-taking and prosocial behavior.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants viewed yearbook photos of their classmates from school, with the task adapted from previous studies to examine neural tracking of popularity.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants viewed yearbook photos based on sociometric ratings, with the task adapted to examine neural tracking of popularity.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants reported on how much they feel 19 different behavioral tendencies apply to them, focusing on prosocial behavior.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Participants rated 19 behavioral tendencies on a 5-point scale, focusing on four subscales related to prosocial behavior.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants reported on their frequency of engaging in 14 risky behaviors, including rule breaking, substance use, and dangerous behavior.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Participants rated their engagement in risky behaviors on a 4-point scale, including questions about rule breaking, substance use, and dangerous behavior.

StudyObjective: Test the prediction that there are dissociable brain networks reflecting the associative strength model and the expectancy model of Pavlovian fear conditioning, consistent with two-system theories of threat and fear reactivity.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants rated their expectation of receiving shock during the inter-trial interval.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: A repeated-measures ANOVA on expectancy ratings performed with trial sequence (6 levels) as a within-subject variable.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Analyzed brain activity across various conditions using univariate analysis.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The analysis was conducted using FSL software with a voxel-level threshold of Z > 2.3 and a corrected cluster size probability of   P   = 0.05.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Conducted a region-of-interest analysis on the bilateral amygdala.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The amygdala ROI was created by taking only the areas of overlap between the anatomical amygdala mask from the Harvard–Oxford atlas thresholded at 50% and regions of bilateral amygdala significantly activated in the whole-brain Shock > No shock analysis.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Analyzed the fifth FIR bin corresponding to 8–10 seconds after CS onset.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The analysis was conducted using FSL software with a voxel-level threshold of Z > 2.3 and a corrected cluster size probability of   P   = 0.05.

StudyObjective: To determine if iTBS could enhance semantic and executive task processing in healthy middle-aged to older adults.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A task that requires participants to decide whether an auditory stimulus matches with a presented image via a yes/no-button press.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In this study, the semantic judgment task included 266 volumes of fMRI data.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A task that requires participants to decide whether an auditory stimulus matches with a presented image via a yes/no-button press.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In this study, the tone judgment task included 24 items per condition of tone judgment.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Each participant saw a list of 20 words (one word every 2 seconds), followed by a 30-second distractor task. Then, they had 1 minute to recall as many words as possible.

StudyObjective: To identify activation patterns that are unique to exploration and exploitation, thereby helping identify to what degree we can theoretically understand these choices within an opponent processing model.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants make decisions to either explore new options or exploit known options.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants make decisions to either explore new options or exploit known options.
TaskMetrics: activation in the dorsal lateral prefrontal cortex, anterior insula, and anterior cingulate cortex during exploration versus exploitation

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A classic inhibitory control task measuring both reaction time and error rates in response to no-go stimuli.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: In this study, the Go/No-Go task included 4 blocks, each with 30 trials. Each trial lasted 2 seconds, with a 1-second inter-trial interval. Subjects were instructed to press a button upon seeing 'go' stimuli and to refrain from pressing for 'no-go' stimuli.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Subjects rested with eyes open for baseline functional connectivity measurements.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed a 5-minute resting-state scan in a single continuous run, instructed to keep their eyes open and minimize movement.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.

StudyObjective: To examine self-reported rumination in association with rejection-related neural activity and connectivity in adolescent girls.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: A social evaluation fMRI task where participants received feedback indicating whether each of 60 adolescents were interested in chatting with them (acceptance), did not want to interact with the participants (rejection), or did not rate their interest (not rated), and reported how receiving this social feedback made them feel.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants were asked to classify half of the 60 adolescents' photographs into the peers that they wanted to chat with (liked peers) and another half of the photographs into the peers that they did not want to chat with (unliked peers). At the second visit, in the fMRI scanner, participants received feedback indicating whether each of 60 adolescents were interested in chatting with them (acceptance) or not (rejection) or did not rate their interest (not rated), and reported how receiving this social feedback made them feel.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: A short-term memory task that measures recall of recently presented words.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Each participant saw a list of 20 words (one word every 2 seconds), followed by a 30-second distractor task. Then, they had 1 minute to recall as many words as possible.

StudyObjective: Investigate the neural tracking of social hierarchies in adolescents’ real-world social networks.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants viewed yearbook photos of their peers from their school and grade.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: The task was adapted from  , in which adolescents viewed yearbook photos of their peers from their school and grade.

fMRITasks.TaskDescription: Participants rested with eyes open for baseline functional connectivity measurements.
fMRITasks.DesignDetails: Participants completed a 5-minute resting-state scan in a single continuous run, instructed to keep their eyes open and minimize movement.

BehavioralTasks.TaskDescription: Participants completed peer sociometric nominations of their grade at school.
BehavioralTasks.DesignDetails: Sociometric nominations were obtained in school-based testing sessions at each wave. A total of 873 consented and assented adolescents participated in school-based assessments (including sociometric nominations) at wave 1. At wave 1, 148 adolescents were enrolled in fMRI data collection (see supplementary material for recruitment details). To account for attrition, an additional 30 participants were recruited at wave 2, during which the Classmates fMRI task was collected from January to September 2018. The resulting sample included 178 participants.
